segments.text: questions of this would have to be when, where were you when you heard the closing or the official closing?
I was in Isfahan, Iran.
And I was a, quote, civilian, unquote, instructor pilot working for Bell Helicopter International.
We were training the Shah's Air Force.
And as an aside to that, I used to believe I could teach a monkey to fly a helicopter if I had enough bananas.
But after my trip to Iran, I don't believe that anymore.
But I was in Isfahan the day it was announced that the war was officially over.
And I can't remember exactly how I felt.
I guess a little bit of everything.
A little happy, a little sad, a little glad.
Very cynical.
Very simple.
And it occurred to me that the night before I had had dinner at the Karush Hotel in Isfahan with two Russian mining engineers whose acquaintances I had made while I was there.
That's when I began to not hate Russians and just hate Communists.
He was a pretty nice guy.
And they spoke pretty good English.
They speak no Russian.
But that's where I was at when it was announced.
And a lot of us, you know, we were all, most of us, Vietnam veterans.
And the gamut of comments were flying around the place.
But I guess all of us were just a little bit relieved that it was finally over.
And we were all sad because we knew we didn't win.
It's hard for us to say we lost it.
We never lost a battle.
We just didn't win the war.
But it wasn't our fault.
But that's another subject.
And I saw those two fine Russian gentlemen a few days later.
And they were very polite.
and not mentioning it.
So I mentioned it.
I said, did you hear the war is over?
And it embarrassed me.
And then we all laughed about it.
And we went away.
I don't think the fool in Normandy ever hit me for a couple of years.
Until I knew it was finally ended.
But over
and never be over.
On the ribbon we wear that was given to us by the Vietnamese government, a little green and white one, is called the Vietnam Campaign Medal.
And there's a little bar on it that has a single date, 1960 until, and there's no other date.
1975 is not on there.
And that pretty much says it.
For a lot of us, in one degree or another, it will never be over.
I've been very fortunate.
I've come out of it.
I know so many others.
It's destroyed their lives.
And it got to a certain point where they just couldn't recover.
But it was finished in the spring of 1975.
It was ended, but it's not over.
But I'll never forget where I was at when I heard it.
It was in a park hotel by the river in Isfahan, the religious capital of the Persian world.
You were saying that it's not over.
How do you feel that overall today, you know, how America's treated you and treats the Vietnam vets?
I met a guy here several years ago.
It was a disabled American veteran service officer with a DAV.
He showed me some figures that absolutely astounded me.
And I think about that, and it's really sad.
258,000 known suicides.
Vietnam veterans.
I mean, there were
Clear cut, no doubt about it.
One way or another, they did themselves in.
Left a note, made it clear where.
An additional 250,000 highly suspect deaths.
The example he used to me was one that he had that was fairly indicative of his arrest.
A guy had taken out a

$100,000 insurance policy, double indemnity accident insurance policy, and three days later was killed in a single car accident on a clear day, stoned sober, and hit a bridge button at 90 miles an hour.
Left a wife and a couple of kids.
Left them with 100 grand.
Things like that.
That's a half a million people.
I'm fairly well pleased with it.
It seemed to be a little patronizing at first, but thank God I got over that.
The main thing was that these $258,000 and then the additional $200,000, for them it's too little, too late.
I mentioned patronized.
I know a lot of people that feel like they're being patronized.
And slowly but surely, hopefully they'll get over that.
I felt it too, and I still see it from time to time.
I know how to recognize it when I do see it, and I'm not very nice in my reaction to it.
I respond to it very negatively, and I let the guilty individual know real quick that I don't like to be patronized.
It's unfortunate that I don't have any control over that.
I couldn't be a little bit more diplomatic about it because it really happens at the most inopportune times.
I don't particularly care where I'm at or who I'm with.
If I'm being patronized about that particular thing, I unload on them.
I don't care who they are.
I don't care what the consequences are.
And that's not right either.
And hopefully I'll get over that too and be a little bit more diplomatic about it and ignore the idiots when they do those things.
But there's so many people still out there that, I don't know, they're swinging after the bell.
They want something else to happen to make it all worth it.
To make it valuable.
And they've been burnt so long and so hard that the light just can't get through.
On my own particular...
back when they started talking about building the wall, the Vietnam Memorial.
There was a hole in the ground.
It was black and dark, ominous.
I said, no, no good.
But I look on it now, I've never been there.
I want to go.
I can't afford it.
But I look on it now, and I hear what other guys have had to say about it, and it's right.
It's perfect.
Couldn't be any more perfect.
When you look at the names on that wall and see your own face there.

And like Mason said, the day they dedicated it, he saw his own face there and the rain was coming down and the droplets were running down the wall and he saw his face and the rain was like the wall had tears.
And it was, it overwhelmed me.
So it does seem to be perfect now.
But back then when it first started, to me it was very pessimistic.
I was very bitter.
Very hard.
Wouldn't talk about it.
Wouldn't let anyone in my shell.
Wouldn't forgive.
Wouldn't lay it down.
Didn't want to.
I wanted to sit there and say, you owe me.
You owe me big.
But I got over that.
I got through it.
And I accept it.
And when someone says to me now, thanks, Vietnam vet, I say, you're welcome.
Because all any of us ever wanted was respect.
respect that we love this country as much as anybody else does.
That we were drawn into a thing that was bigger than any of us and without a control and no one, no one knew what to do about it.
So I just say you're welcome.
This is why I've let you interview me about this.
Because I really believe now that the young people of your generation want to know.
Oddly enough, I'm in the generation that's kind of on the fringe.
I really shouldn't have been there.
I was in my late 20s.
I was 27 years old when I went to Vietnam.
Thank you.
41 through 68.
Yeah, 27.
On my 27th birthday.
I was an old man.
Even when I was in flight school, I was the second oldest one in the class.
The other guy was 35.
I was 27.
Everybody else was 19 and 20 and 21.
We were the two old men.
Pop and Grandpa, that's what they called us.
I really shouldn't have been there.
I didn't have to be there.
People in my generation, most of them weren't.
But it's that other generation.
They're coming now.
And your generation wants to know what happened to them.
They want to know what happened to their moms and their dads.
They want to know what happened to their Uncle Charlie.
Why is he that way?
What happened with Uncle Charlie?
Why did my dad go away?
Why did my dad come back?
Why is my mom that way?
They want to know.
And it's up to us to tell you to pass it on.
At least you be condemned to repeat the past.
Don't do it.
Don't let it happen again.
There will be wars.
That's going to happen.
Nothing you're going to do is going to stop it.
People have tried for generations, hundreds of generations, to stop a war, and all they've managed to do is interrupt.
And that's nice.
A little period of peace and prosperity off and on.
But you're not going to stop on this side of the second coming.
It will not happen.
But you've got to have one.
Do it right.
Go out to win.
Go all out.
Call it total war.
Call it whatever you want to.
But make the enemy pay.
Make it more costly for him to conduct a war
than it is for you.
It has a price.
It's freedom that we enjoy.
And the price is paid in blood, not dollars.
That's why there's a red in that flag.
That's what it's for.
You're saying what you want to leave, I mean, as a note to the
young people of the day, my generation, maybe even the generation after me.
What else would you like to say to them?
Like I said, your generation wants to know what happened to your dad's generation and mine from what.
And I feel it incumbent upon me from time to time to tell you.
Not to lecture you, but to teach you.
I was deadly serious about my chosen way of life.
I chose it when I was just but a child.
My earliest memory is when I was four years old, standing on the railroad platform in Gainesville, Texas, during World War II, seeing an uncle of mine off to the battle in Europe on a troop train.
The excitement of that day and what was going on

the train soldiers and people and everybody proud and one thing or another and just the gamut of emotions marked my thinking and from that early age i wanted to be a soldier and i think it was planted in me before i was born so i was very very serious about my way of life well some people even think that i held the beliefs of the centuries
and that would come home with your shield or on it.
In fact, one dear friend of mine, a fellow pilot, he once described me as one who would be willing to die for an idea or with it.
Steve was being cynical when he said,
And he used to pick on me a lot about things like that, but I took it as a great compliment because he was right.
He was absolutely right.
My whole being has been that.
To die for an idea or with it.
This idea that we have about the liberties that we enjoy is something worth dying for.
I once heard a man say,
You've got to stand for something or you'll fall for anything.
And that marked my thinking also.
But I had to make choices like everybody does.
And my whole upbringing was stand for something.
Be counted on.
You're one of many, but be that one.
And don't back off.
Be honest in your decisions.
Be careful in your selection.
But once you've made your choice, stand with it.
If you're wrong, change it.
If you're not, don't give up.
Never, ever, ever give up.
I sensed somewhere along the line that I really came to realize that I'd been betrayed by the very system that I was sworn to defend.
And as I've said several times, I became very bitter and disillusioned about almost everything that I believed in.
From literally from the Boy Scouts to God.
I reached a point where I trusted absolutely nothing that was not of my own invention.
Nothing.
Only none of my inventions worked, whether they be physical or mental.
They just didn't seem to work.
I firmly believe, and I've got the evidence more than any man would need,

the god that i believe in and his infinite mercy physically delivered me from the torment that i was going through and in doing so allowed me to begin to see glimpses of the truth of what happened the betrayal of honest men doing their duty as they've been taught by generations before them is beyond my ability to comprehend
And I mentioned it a couple of times already, but it is so enormous, this betrayal.
Vengeance can never wipe it out.
Only forgiveness can clear away that stain.
It must never happen again.
And it is incumbent upon your generation to see to it that it doesn't.
